abstract.text: A self-administered validated (Cronbach alpha= 0.077) questionnaire was used to assess 2 knowledge, attitude and practice among HCPs in Pakistan regarding COVID-19. Findings 3 showed HCPs had good knowledge (93.2%, n=386), positive attitude (8.43±1.78) and good 4 practice (88.7%, n=367) regarding COVID-19. HCPs perceived that limited infection control 5 material (50.7%, n=210) and poor knowledge regarding transmission (40.6%, n=168) are the 6 major barriers in infection control practice. Regression analysis indicated pharmacist role (OR: 7 2.247, 95% CI: 1.11-4.55, P=0.025) was the substantial determinant of good practice. HCPs in 8 Pakistan have good knowledge, yet, there were areas where gaps in knowledge and practice were 9 observed.

body_text.text: Healthcare professionals (HCPs) of all levels and groups are involved in caring for patients with 3 this highly transmittable pathogen. COVID-19 has posed serious occupational health risk to the 4 HCP owing to their frequent exposure to infected individuals [5] . Literature suggest that lack of 5 knowledge and misunderstandings among HCPs leads to delayed diagnosis, spread of disease 6 and poor infection control practice. Several thousand healthcare workers have already been 7 infected, mainly in China [5] . Preventing intrahospital transmission of the communicable disease 8 is therefore a priority.

Amidst to current pandemic, the WHO has issued several guidelines, started online courses and 10 training sessions to raise awareness and preparedness regarding prevention and control of 11 COVID-19 among HCPs [6] . Knowledge, attitude, and practice survey provides a suitable 12 format to evaluate existing programs and to identify effective strategies for behavior change in 13 society. Currently, there is scarce information regarding the awareness level of HCPs in Pakistan, 14 Therefore, the present study aimed to identify the current status of knowledge, attitude and 15 practices regarding COVID-19 among healthcare professionals in Pakistan. In addition, study 16 highlighted the information sources utilized and barriers in infection control perceived by HCPs.

A multi-centric cross-sectional survey-based study was conducted during the month of March 20 2020, during the days of strict lockdown to implement social distancing to avoid spread of 21 pandemic. As it was not feasible to conduct a population-based survey in this critical condition, the investigators selected an online data collection method. Sample size calculated by Raosoft 1 was 377 assuming a response rate of 50%, confidence interval (CI) 95%, Z as 1.96, and margin 2 of error as 5%. Considering, an additional 10% (n=37) for any error in questionnaire filling, a 3 final sample size of 414 will be required. Survey was started on 25, March 2020, and response 4 acceptance was closed (05-April 2020) when required sample size was achieved.

The study population eligible for participation in this survey was HCPs including doctors, 6 pharmacists, and nurses from all healthcare facilities in Punjab. A questionnaire was designed on 7 google forms and link generated was shared on WhatsApp groups of HCPs. Link was also shared 8 personally to HCPs who were in contact list of investigators. Respondents from other provinces 9 were also eligible to participate if they are willing to fill the questionnaire. Each question was respondent on 5-point Likert scale as follows strongly agree, agree, 12 undecided, disagree, and strongly disagree. Responses were presented as frequencies and 13 percentages.

The study was performed in accordance to declaration of Helsinki. Due to lockdown, universities 16 were closed, hence study protocol was approved from Hospital board (756/THQ/HR). Study 17 questionnaire contained consent portion that stated purpose, nature of survey, study objectives, 18 volunteer participation, declaration of confidentiality and anonymity.
Descriptive and inferential statistics were applied by using SPSS V.21. Chi-square tests,

Independent sample t-test and one-way ANOVA analysis were applied to find difference in knowledge, attitude and practice of HCPs by demographic characteristics. Pearson-rank 1 correlation tests were applied to find any correlation between knowledge, attitude and practice 2 sections. To find possible determinants of good knowledge and practice, a binary logistic 3 regression analysis will be applied and expressed as odds ratio (OR) and 95% confidence interval 4 (CI). A p value of less than 0.05 will be considered as significant in all tests. Firstly, it is a cross-sectional study conducted 8 during lockdown period, and universities were also closed, therefore institutional review board 9 was not approached. Secondly, this is an online survey, responses mainly depend upon honesty 10 and partly affected by recall ability and thus may subject to recall bias. FIGREF1.text: instrument was designed based on extensive literature review, course material 12 regarding emerging respiratory diseases including COVID-19 byWHO [7]. After an initial draft 13 of the questionnaire designed, it was validated in 2 steps. Firstly, the study instrument was sent 14 to researchers and professionals from medical backgrounds (pharmacists and physicians) to give 15 their expert opinion with respect to its simplicity, relativity and importance. Secondly, a pilot16 study was conducted by selecting a small sample of health care professionals (n = 40) who gave 17 their opinions on making the questionnaire simpler and shorter. Participants from all healthcare 18 professions were selected for the pilot study. Reliability coefficient was calculated by using The questionnaire consisted of questions assessing demographics, information source, 1 knowledge, attitude, practice toward COVID-19 and perceived barriers to infection control 2 practice (Supplementary file 1). Demographic characteristics included were gender, age, 3 profession and experience, and one item regarding source of information about COVID-19. 4 Knowledge section comprised of 14 items and each question was responded as Yes, No and I 5 don't know. The correct answer was marked as 1 while wrong answer was marked as 0. Attitude 6 section comprised of 7 items and response of each item was recorded on 5-point Likert scale as 7 follows strongly agree (1-point), agree (2-point), Undecided (3-point), disagree (4-point), and 8 strongly disagree (5-point). Practice section included 6 items and each item was responded as 9 Yes (1-point), No (0-point), and Sometimes (0-point). 10 Seven items assessed the perception of HCPs regrading barriers in infection control practice.

FIGREF6.text: current survey demonstrated that majority of HCPs have good knowledge (93.2%, 15 n=386), positive attitude (mean 8.43) and good practice (88.7%, n=367) towards COVID-19 16 (Table I). Of note that, 87.68% (n=363) HCPs utilized social media as main source of 17 information followed by radio & television (45.89%, n=190) and seniors/other colleagues 18 (42.51%, n=176) (Fig. 1, Supplementary file 1). Findings are consistent with different studies 19 [6,8] which also reported majority of HCPs use social media to seek information regarding 20 COVID-19 [6]. HCPs should consult reliable sources such as guidelines and reports published by important as in this global pandemic, there is also a pandemic of misinformation regarding 1 COVID-19; a serious concern might lead to xenophobia in the world as already warned by 2 scientists and WHO officials [6]. 3 Current findings of good knowledge (93.2%, n=386) among HCPs is in line with findings of 4 Giao et al and Shi et al who reported that 88.4% and 89.51% participants respectively have 5 sufficient knowledge regarding COVID-19 [8]. While another study reported that only 56.5% 6 respondents have sufficient knowledge regarding transmission, symptoms and treatment of 7COVID-19 [9]. Present findings provide confidence in terms of healthcare professional's 8 knowledge regarding COVID-19 symptoms, transmission and preventive measures. This is of 9 more significance in current scenario when there is no vaccine and research is ongoing so HCPs 10 must aware of all the updates and take precautions in treating and preventing the infection.
